name: Julia
comment info:
The graph shows the average egg price over time generally increased, but the price fluctuated greatly in many years.  The most noticeable price fluctuations occurred around 2004, 2008, 2015, and 2022.  The first price spike occurred in 2004 but returned to a lower price quickly.  Around 2008, the egg price spiked, but increased and decreased more gradually than the other years.  The 2008 spike was the first time egg price exceeded $3.  In 2015, the average price of a dozen eggs increased by about $1 then dropped by about $1.50.  The most recent recorded increase shows a steep increase by nearly $2.50 in one year.  Because the writers adjusted for inflation, I wonder what major events relate to the price spikes, and if we can categorize the events.  For example, do the price spikes relate to political strife such as a war, or was there a disease plaguing major egg production areas, so people harvested fewer eggs?   I do not eat eggs frequently, so I did not notice the increased egg prices, but the article highlights that an American person “consumed an average of 278 eggs last year,” so Americans must allocate more funds to groceries, or consume fewer eggs (Network).  Allocating more funds to groceries implies that people either work more hours at jobs, or depreciate other areas in their life such as entertainment and utilities.  Consuming fewer eggs suggests people change their diets and find egg alternatives.  

Egg-streme Price Spikes: Don’t Put Eggs in Your Basket

With the prices of eggs becoming more expensive, lower income individuals are less likely to be able to afford them in more recent years than they were before. This eliminates a healthy option available to them for meals, making them more likely to turn to less healthy alternatives that are high in sugars and fats.  

Egg Prices on the Rise – But for Good This Time

name: Jamie Porter
comment info:
In this graph, I notice that from the year 2000 to December 2022, the monthly average price of a dozen eggs has gradually increased from around $1.50 to nearly $4.25. name: Alexis Frialda
comment info:
1) I notice that the price of feeding grains is at the highest it has been in almost a decade, and according to the right graph, there was an outbreak of avian flu in March and April that led to the loss of a combined 25 million hens. These two factors have led to the highest price of eggs recorded in this century; a peak of $4.25 in December of 2022.

2) I wonder if the loss of hens and the growing price of grains has actually harmed farming corporations. The most recent articles I've seen on the topic has claimed that these companies have been recording record profits in their egg sales, which seems to be the opposite of what is expected after such a large hit to egg production. Are the grain prices and avian flu really the cause of high egg prices? Or is there a lurking variable underneath it all?

3) Grocery prices are one of the places where low-income communities get hit hardest by inflation. When every dollar counts in a weekly grocery trip, the insane price of eggs is something that really weighs in your pockets after only a couple months. Personally, people in my community have been helping out where it's needed by sharing cartons of eggs in their workplaces, and my neighbors have traded eggs with us for fish and other meats. While the situation might not be ideal, it helps highlight the way that communities lend help in times of need. 

4) Getting to the Yolk of It: What's REALLY Causing Those Egg Prices?

name: Ashley Alv. (P5)
comment info:
1. I've noticed that egg prices will hit an all-time high in December 2022. The path to $4.25 has risen and fallen steadily over the years, with the most notable peaks occurring in 2008, 2016, and 2022. The lowest peaks occurred in the 2000s and near the beginning of COVID in 2019. Looking at the extra graph "Annual prices of grains used for feed," it does appear that the grain price had a significant impact on the price of eggs around the year 2012 as the prices had reached their peak.
2. Is the sharp rise in egg prices due to the loss of more than 15 million egg-laying birds due to avian flu in 2022? Also, why were egg prices significantly lower in the years leading up to the pandemic and for the first two years following it?
3. This is significant in my community because the majority of us have had to deal with the financial consequences of COVID, and as the price of eggs rises, so does the price of everything else. Simple foods like eggs have become more expensive for people in financial difficulty. There is more of a supply problem than a demand problem, though both are present. Egg prices are affected by the chickens that lay the eggs, which are currently more expensive to feed. With all these factors that contribute to the supply of eggs, being able to provide food for families is more difficult and more of a strain than ever.
4. What is Up with the Eggflation: Prices are More Scrambled than Ever!

What makes you think that the price of grain does not have an effect on the price of eggs?  What is the percentage change in price of grains?  Why was this happening?  What is the relationship of the timing of paying for grain and the egg prices?

Is this graph have more than you expected to think about when noticings and wondering?  Good thing you have the ability to search online for some answers.

Please return Friday when we will reveal the free link to the New York Times article that included this graph.  The article has a more complete explanation of why egg prices have “cracked.”
